diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.rationale: SLE can affect the brain causing psychosis and delirium, the heart leading to acute pericarditis, and joints resulting in synovitis and various arthropathies.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatic Fever
diagnoses.rationale: Rheumatic fever, a complication of untreated strep throat, can lead to migratory arthropathy, carditis including pericarditis, and in rare cases, Sydenham's chorea, presenting as acute psychosis.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease
diagnoses.rationale: This disease can show overlapping symptoms of lupus, scleroderma, and polymyositis, including arthritic symptoms, pericarditis, and potential CNS involvement leading to delirium or psychosis.

diagnoses.name: Infectious Endocarditis
diagnoses.rationale: While primarily involving heart valves, infectious endocarditis can also lead to acute pericarditis, joint pains or arthropathy, and in severe cases, delirium or psychosis due to septic emboli or immune-mediated mechanisms.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.rationale: Sarcoidosis can present with granulomas in any organ system, including joints (arthropathy), heart (pericarditis), and the CNS (delirium/psychosis).

diagnoses.name: Viral Infection (e.g., HIV, Hepatitis C)
diagnoses.rationale: Certain viral infections like HIV and Hepatitis C can lead to a myriad of symptoms including acute pericarditis, arthritis, and affect the central nervous system leading to delirium or psychosis.

diagnoses.name: Post-Cardiac Injury Syndromes
diagnoses.rationale: After myocardial infarction or cardiac surgery, individuals can develop pericarditis, pleuritis, and possibly joint symptoms, akin to Dressler's syndrome.

diagnoses.name: Gout
diagnoses.rationale: An acute presentation of gout might present with synovitis and arthropathy, with systemic inflammation potentially involving the pericardium and rarely affecting mental status.

diagnoses.name: Drug-Induced Lupus
diagnoses.rationale: Certain medications can lead to a lupus-like syndrome manifesting as acute pericarditis, arthropathy, and in rare instances, central nervous system involvement including delirium or psychosis.

diagnoses.name: Psychiatric Disorders with Somatic Symptoms
diagnoses.rationale: Primary psychiatric disorders such as schizophrenia can present with psychosis and contrive somatic symptoms including joint pains and chest pain, which might mimic pericarditis or synovitis in the setting of delirium.

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: A disease involving abnormal collections of inflammatory cells that form lumps known as granulomas. The condition can affect the lymph nodes, eyes, and go along with skin manifestations and respiratory problems.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's disease
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder causing inflammation in blood vessels throughout your body. The signs and symptoms of Behçet's disease — which may include mouth sores, genital sores, eye inflammation, and skin rashes — can vary from person to person.

diagnoses.name: Tuberculosis
diagnoses.description: A potentially serious infectious bacterial disease that mainly affects the lungs but can also affect lymph nodes, leading to lymphadenopathy, and manifest with cough and general malaise.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can cause inflammation and pain in any part of your body. It's characterized by periods of illness, called flares, and periods of wellness, or remission. It can present with a wide range of symptoms, including those listed.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: Human immunodeficiency virus/acquired immunodeficiency syndrome is a spectrum of conditions caused by infection with the HIV. It can lead to weakened immunity and present with lymphadenopathy, skin issues, and respiratory symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Non-Hodgkin Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer that begins in lymphocytes, a type of white blood cells which are part of the body's immune system. Symptoms can include lymphadenopathy, fever, night sweats, weight loss, and cough.

diagnoses.name: Iron Deficiency Anemia
diagnoses.description: A common type of anemia, a condition in which blood lacks adequate healthy red blood cells. Hypoferritinemia indicates low iron storage in the body, leading to symptoms like fatigue and weakness.

diagnoses.name: Stevens-Johnson Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare, serious disorder of your skin and mucous membranes. It's usually a reaction to a medication or an infection. Symptoms may include flu-like symptoms followed by a painful red or purplish rash that spreads and blisters.

diagnoses.name: Reactive Arthritis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory condition that develops in response to an infection in another part of your body. It can cause inflammation of the eyes, urinary tract, and skin, and can include conjunctivitis and skin lesions or ulcers.

diagnoses.name: Lymphogranuloma Venereum
diagnoses.description: A sexually transmitted infection caused by three types of the Chlamydia trachomatis bacterium. It affects the lymphatic system and can result in genital and rectal ulcers, swollen lymph nodes, and rectal inflammation.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Liver Disease/Cirrhosis
diagnoses.rationale: Chronic liver disease can lead to fibrosis (scarring of the liver tissue), which may contribute to thrombocytopenia (low platelet count) due to the spleen enlarging and sequestering platelets. Liver disease can also cause issues with blood clotting, leading to both bleeding and clotting disorders, potentially contributing to hemorrhoids and thromboembolic disease.

diagnoses.name: Myeloproliferative Disorders
diagnoses.rationale: These disorders (e.g., polycythemia vera, essential thrombocythemia) can lead to an increased risk of blood clots (thromboembolic disease), as well as thrombocytopenia in certain phases or conditions. Symptoms can also include vision problems and difficulty concentrating.

diagnoses.name: Hyperthyroidism
diagnoses.rationale: Though less direct, hyperthyroidism can cause difficulty concentrating, might contribute to eye symptoms (including difficulty focusing vision due to Grave's opthalmopathy), and can indirectly affect platelet function and thus coagulability. It would be less directly related to fibrosis and hemorrhoids but can affect overall systemic health.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Kidney Disease
diagnoses.rationale: Like liver disease, chronic kidney disease (CKD) can lead to a buildup of toxins in the blood, which can affect the ability to concentrate and focus vision. CKD can also result in a decrease in platelet function (contributing to thrombocytopenia) and increase the risk of thromboembolic events.

diagnoses.name: Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: This condition, often triggered by an infection, can lead to thrombocytopenia, renal failure (which may cause difficulty concentrating due to toxin buildup), thromboembolic events, and possibly fibrotic changes in the kidney over time.

diagnoses.name: Antiphospholipid Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: An autoimmune disorder characterized by thrombosis (blood clots) and pregnancy complications in addition to thrombocytopenia. It can result in thromboembolic disease and possibly affect vision though retinal clots or other mechanisms.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.rationale: A disease that leads to granulomas (nodules of inflamed tissue) in various parts of the body, including the eye which can affect vision, and lungs leading to fibrosis. It can also affect the bone marrow, contributing to thrombocytopenia.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.rationale: Over time, diabetes can lead to complications including eye troubles (such as diabetic retinopathy, which can affect vision), and can also contribute to thrombocytopenia and thromboembolic diseases due to poor circulation and endothelial dysfunction.

diagnoses.name: Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD)
diagnoses.rationale: Including Crohn’s disease and ulcerative colitis, IBD can contribute to thrombocytopenia, increase the risk of thromboembolic disease due to inflammation in the body, cause hemorrhoids due to frequent bowel movements or straining, and may be associated with liver fibrosis in overlapping liver conditions such as primary sclerosing cholangitis.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.rationale: HIV/AIDS can result in thrombocytopenia, and individuals with advanced disease may experience issues related to fibrosis, particularly in the context of related infections or complications such as opportunistic infections impacting vision and cognitive functions leading to difficulty concentrating. Thromboembolic disease risk is also higher.

diagnoses: Inflammatory Bowel Disease (e.g., Crohn's Disease, Ulcerative Colitis)
Panic Disorder or Acute Stress Reaction

diagnoses.name: Graves' Disease
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder and a common cause of hyperthyroidism that can lead to a range of systemic symptoms including alterations in metabolism and cardiovascular system.

diagnoses.name: Thyroid Cancer
diagnoses.description: Cancer that forms in the thyroid gland, potentially leading to hyperthyroidism among other symptoms; could indirectly influence vascular anomalies through the proliferation of abnormal tissues.

diagnoses.name: Hashimoto's Thyroiditis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune condition that can initially present with symptoms of hyperthyroidism but typically progresses to hypothyroidism; its inflammation might be linked to vascular anomalies.

diagnoses.name: Polyarteritis Nodosa
diagnoses.description: A rare autoimmune disease that can cause atherosclerosis, and potentially lead to vascular anomalies; it may indirectly affect the thyroid gland.

diagnoses.name: Fibromuscular Dysplasia
diagnoses.description: A condition that causes growth of fibrous tissue in the walls of medium-sized arteries and can lead to vascular anomalies, hypertension, and indirectly affect organs like the thyroid.

diagnoses.name: Meniere's Disease
diagnoses.description: A disorder of the inner ear causing vertigo and tinnitus. While it is not directly related to hyperthyroidism or vascular anomalies, systemic diseases can sometimes manifest with a broad range of symptoms including those affecting auditory perceptions.

diagnoses.name: Pulsatile Tinnitus
diagnoses.description: A form of tinnitus that is synchronized with the patient's heartbeat. It can be associated with various vascular anomalies or conditions such as atherosclerosis.

diagnoses.name: Oral Squamous Cell Carcinoma
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer that can cause leukoplakia. Risk factors could include systemic diseases that impact immune response or are associated with chronic inflammation, possibly linked to chronic illnesses affecting the thyroid.

diagnoses.name: Lichen Planus
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory condition affecting mucous membranes inside the mouth, possibly presenting as leukoplakia. While not directly correlated, systemic autoimmune disorders could have a non-specific association.

diagnoses.name: Hypertension
diagnoses.description: High blood pressure is a common condition that can link hyperthyroidism, vascular anomalies, and atherosclerosis through increased cardiovascular strain.

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests
diagnoses: Diabetes Mellitus Type 2 with Renal Complications

diagnoses.name: Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD)
diagnoses.reason: Directly matches the symptom of obsessive-compulsive behavior and can also cause secondary anxiety.

diagnoses.name: Generalized Anxiety Disorder
diagnoses.reason: Matches the symptom of anxiety; can be associated with obsessive-compulsive behavior.

diagnoses.name: Celiac Disease
diagnoses.reason: Autoimmune disorder leading to malabsorption when consuming gluten; can present with anxiety and indirectly with other neurological symptoms.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.reason: Can cause lymphadenopathy, malabsorption, anxiety, and neurological symptoms affecting vision.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.reason: An autoimmune disorder that can cause neurological symptoms and has been associated with anxiety; may lead to dry eyes, possibly contributing to difficulty focusing vision.

diagnoses.name: Lupus (Systemic Lupus Erythematosus)
diagnoses.reason: An autoimmune disease that can cause a wide range of symptoms including lymphadenopathy and neurological symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.reason: Caused by Borrelia bacteria from a tick bite; can lead to lymphadenopathy, neurological symptoms, and anxiety.

diagnoses.name: Tuberculosis
diagnoses.reason: An infectious disease that can cause lymphadenopathy. If it affects the gut, it might lead to malabsorption.

diagnoses.name: Thyroid Disorders (Hypothyroidism/Hyperthyroidism)
diagnoses.reason: Can cause anxiety, malabsorption, and lead to eye issues, sometimes affecting vision focus.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
diagnoses.reason: Though primarily marked by extreme fatigue, patients may experience concentration issues, anxiety, and immune system abnormalities like swollen lymph nodes.

diagnoses.name: Cushing's Syndrome
diagnoses.reasoning: Cushing's syndrome can cause malabsorption, increased susceptibility to infections due to immunosuppression, anxiety as a psychological symptom, and striae due to skin changes. Polycythemia may not be a direct symptom but can be associated due to complex hormonal interactions.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.reasoning: HIV/AIDS can lead to malabsorption, particularly in advanced stages, significantly increased susceptibility to infections due to immunodeficiency, and may cause anxiety as part of its psychological impact. HIV/AIDS itself does not directly cause polycythemia or striae but may be associated with complications or co-infections that could.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Kidney Disease
diagnoses.reasoning: Chronic kidney disease can lead to increased susceptibility to infections due to impaired immune function, anxiety due to the stress of the illness, and striae as part of skin changes. Malabsorption is less directly associated but can occur due to complications. Polycythemia can occur in chronic kidney disease due to increased erythropoietin production.

diagnoses.name: Inflammatory Bowel Disease
diagnoses.reasoning: Inflammatory bowel disease, including Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis, often causes malabsorption. It can also lead to an increased susceptibility to infections due to both the disease and treatments. Anxiety is common due to the chronic nature of the disease. Striae may occur, particularly with steroid use. Polycythemia may appear due to dehydration.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Liver Disease
diagnoses.reasoning: Chronic liver disease can cause malabsorption, especially of fats and fat-soluble vitamins. Increased susceptibility to infections occurs due to immunosuppression. Anxiety may be related to the stress of the illness, and striae are commonly seen with cirrhosis due to hormonal imbalances. Polycythemia is less directly linked but may be observed in relation to spleen dysfunction.

diagnoses.name: Addison's Disease
diagnoses.reasoning: Addison's disease leads to increased susceptibility to infections due to adrenal insufficiency, can cause anxiety as a psychological symptom, and may lead to skin changes including striae. Malabsorption is not a typical symptom of Addison’s itself but can occur in the context of autoimmune polyglandular syndromes.

diagnoses.name: Hyperthyroidism/Graves' Disease
diagnoses.reasoning: Hyperthyroidism, especially in the form of Graves' disease, can cause malabsorption, increased susceptibility to infections, and anxiety due to elevated thyroid hormones. Striae are less commonly associated but may occur with significant weight changes or in conjunction with autoimmune manifestations.

diagnoses.name: Tuberculosis
diagnoses.reasoning: Tuberculosis can lead to malabsorption, particularly if the intestines are involved, significantly increased susceptibility to infections due to the impact on the immune system, and anxiety due to the chronic nature of the disease. Striae and polycythemia are not directly associated but could be observed in complicated or co-existing conditions.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.reasoning: Systemic lupus erythematosus can cause malabsorption if the gastrointestinal system is involved, increased susceptibility to infections due to immunosuppression, and anxiety due to the impact of the chronic illness. Striae may also appear, especially with long-term corticosteroid use, which is a common treatment. Polycythemia is less commonly associated but may occur.

diagnoses.name: Zollinger-Ellison Syndrome
diagnoses.reasoning: Zollinger-Ellison syndrome causes malabsorption due to the excessive production of stomach acid, leading to the destruction of the intestinal lining. While it directly causes malabsorption and may lead to an increased susceptibility to infections due to nutrient deficiencies, anxiety, striae, and polycythemia are less directly associated. These symptoms might be indirectly related due to the stress of the illness or as part of paraneoplastic syndromes.

diagnoses: Aspiration pneumonia (secondary to vomiting and causing hypoxia)

diagnoses.name: Anaphylaxis
diagnoses.description: A severe, life-threatening allergic reaction that can lead to hypotension, angioedema, and gastrointestinal symptoms such as diarrhea.

diagnoses.name: Addison's Disease
diagnoses.description: A disorder of the adrenal glands that can cause hypotension, gastrointestinal symptoms like diarrhea, and skin changes.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Inflammatory Demyelinating Polyneuropathy (CIDP)
diagnoses.description: A neurological disorder causing weakness, sensory loss, and autonomic symptoms such as incontinence.

diagnoses.name: Gastroenteritis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the gastrointestinal tract, often causing diarrhea, vomiting, and in some cases, dehydration leading to hypotension.

diagnoses.name: Hereditary Angioedema
diagnoses.description: A genetic disorder that results in recurrent episodes of severe swelling (angioedema), abdominal pain, and in some cases, diarrhea.

diagnoses.name: Non-allergic Rhinitis
diagnoses.description: A condition causing chronic sneezing or a congested, drippy nose with no apparent allergic cause (rhinorrhea), which could be related to autonomic dysfunction.

diagnoses.name: Sepsis
diagnoses.description: A potentially life-threatening condition caused by the body's response to an infection, leading to hypotension and multiple organ dysfunction.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that can affect many systems, leading to a wide range of symptoms including hypotension, skin rashes (which could mimic angioedema), and renal issues causing incontinence.

diagnoses.name: Vasovagal Syncope
diagnoses.description: A common cause of fainting (syncope) that can lead to transient hypotension, often associated with gastrointestinal distress such as diarrhea.

diagnoses.name: Neurogenic Bladder
diagnoses.description: A disorder of the bladder control due to brain, spinal cord, or nerve condition, leading to urinary incontinence, and could accompany various neurological syndromes that also have autonomic dysfunction.

diagnoses: Inflammatory Bowel Disease (e.g., Crohn's Disease, Ulcerative Colitis)
Inflammatory bowel disease (Crohn's disease, Ulcerative colitis)
Dehydration secondary to vomiting and diarrhea
Ectopic pregnancy (in females of reproductive age)

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that affects the brain and spinal cord, causing a range of neurological symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A condition where poor blood flow to the brain results in cell death, causing symptoms depending on the area of the brain affected.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: A type of migraine that's preceded or accompanied by sensory disturbances, including visual impairments like scotoma.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, it’s a brief period of symptoms similar to those of a stroke but usually lasts only a few minutes and causes no permanent damage.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumors
diagnoses.description: Abnormal growths in the brain that can cause a variety of neurological symptoms depending on their location and size.

diagnoses.name: Vitamin B12 Deficiency
diagnoses.description: A lack of B12 can lead to neurological problems, including numbness, tingling, and problems swallowing.

diagnoses.name: Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS)
diagnoses.description: A neurological disease that affects nerve cells in the brain and spinal cord, causing loss of muscle control.

diagnoses.name: Guillain-Barre Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder where the body's immune system attacks the peripheral nerves, causing weakness and tingling in the extremities.

diagnoses.name: Myasthenia Gravis
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune neuromuscular disease that causes weakness in the skeletal muscles, which are responsible for breathing and moving parts of the body, including the arms and legs.

diagnoses.name: Vertebrobasilar Insufficiency
diagnoses.description: A condition arising from restricted blood flow in the arteries at the back of the neck, affecting the circulation to the brain and leading to symptoms like vertigo and numbness.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with aura
diagnoses.description: A type of headache characterized by recurrent attacks of moderate to severe pain. The aura may manifest as visual disturbances, aphasia, or sensory changes before the headache phase.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A medical condition where poor blood flow to the brain results in cell death. Symptoms can include weakness, difficulty speaking, and visual problems.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, it's a brief episode of neurological dysfunction caused by loss of blood flow to the brain. Symptoms mimic those of a stroke but typically resolve within minutes to hours.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: An abnormal growth of cells within the brain or the skull vault. Symptoms can include headaches, weakness, language disturbances, and sensory changes, depending on the tumor's location.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the brain and spinal cord membranes, typically caused by an infection. Symptoms include headache, fever, and a stiff neck, along with potential for photophobia and phonophobia.

diagnoses.name: Encephalitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the brain often caused by a viral infection. Symptoms can include headache, fever, confusion, weakness, and sensitivity to light and noise.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis (MS)
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease affecting the central nervous system. Symptoms can include episodes of weakness, impaired speech (dysarthria), and light/sound sensitivity due to lesions in the nervous system.

diagnoses.name: Epilepsy
diagnoses.description: A neurological disorder marked by sudden recurrent episodes of sensory disturbance, loss of consciousness, or convulsions, associated with abnormal electrical activity in the brain. Postictal state can include aphasia and weakness.

diagnoses.name: Hemorrhagic Stroke
diagnoses.description: Occurs when a blood vessel within the brain leaks or ruptures. It's less common than an ischemic stroke but tends to cause more severe symptoms, including sudden weakness and difficulty with language and understanding.

diagnoses.name: Subarachnoid Hemorrhage
diagnoses.description: Bleeding into the subarachnoid space, which lies between the brain and the surrounding membrane. Sudden, severe headache, often described as the worst headache ever experienced, followed by photophobia, phonophobia, stiffness of the neck, and possibly altered mental status and focal neurological deficits.

diagnoses: Epilepsy (for the seizures, though not directly related to the other symptoms without a clear underlying systemic cause)

Lichen planopilaris (considering its relationship with lichen planus and causing scarring alopecia, but it's crucial to note your term 'nonscarring alopecia' which may hint at a broader dermatological autoimmune process or differential diagnosis)
Autoimmune hemolytic anemia (as a specific diagnosis or as part of another condition)

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.rationale: SLE can present with proteinuria due to kidney involvement, and rarely, nasal ulcers. Seizures can also be a neurological manifestation of the disease.

diagnoses.name: Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (GPA)
diagnoses.rationale: GPA, formerly known as Wegener's granulomatosis, may cause nasal ulcers due to granulomatous inflammation and can lead to kidney disease manifesting as proteinuria.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease
diagnoses.rationale: This disease can have features of multiple connective tissue diseases including systemic lupus erythematosus that could explain proteinuria, and potentially could be associated with seizures.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's Disease
diagnoses.rationale: Though primarily known for causing oral and genital ulcers, it can also present with skin manifestations such as pathergy reaction similar to lichen planus, and in severe cases, CNS involvement causing seizures.

diagnoses.name: Hereditary Hemorrhagic Telangiectasia (HHT)
diagnoses.rationale: HHT is characterized by the presence of multiple telangiectasias and can involve various organs. It does not directly explain seizures or proteinuria but could be part of a more complex syndrome with these symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: Sjögren's can present with systemic symptoms and has been associated with renal involvement, including proteinuria. It can also lead to neurological complications, potentially explaining seizures.

diagnoses.name: Hepatitis C-associated Cryoglobulinemia
diagnoses.rationale: Cryoglobulinemia associated with Hepatitis C can cause a vasculitis leading to proteinuria and skin changes akin to lichen planus, but it is less traditionally associated with seizures.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.rationale: While classically presenting with muscle weakness and dermal findings, it can occasionally have features of vasculitis leading to proteinuria. Seizures are not typically a feature but can occur in severe systemic disease.

diagnoses.name: Antiphospholipid Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: This condition can cause a wide range of symptoms, including renal involvement which may manifest as proteinuria. Neurological manifestations can include seizures.

diagnoses.name: Lupus Nephritis
diagnoses.rationale: A specific manifestation of SLE affecting the kidneys, leading to proteinuria. While it doesn't directly account for the other symptoms, its presence indicates systemic involvement that could potentially explain them.

diagnoses: Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS Syndrome)
